title: Communication & Attachment
description: Discover how your attachment style shapes the way you communicate.

questions.text: How do I communicate when I'm feeling insecure?
choices: I become quieter and more withdrawn
I try to act like everything's fine

therapeutic.rationale: Insecurity communication reveals attachment coping. Reassurance-seekers have anxious activation; withdrawers have avoidant activation; fine-actors mask vulnerability; open-expressers have secure communication. How you communicate when insecure determines whether your partner can actually help.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different insecurity communication creates misunderstanding. The withdrawer seems fine while suffering; the fine-actor may not receive needed support. Communicate directly about what you need.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared insecurity communication means you'll either both reach out or both withdraw. Two withdrawers may both suffer in silence unnecessarily.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you feel insecure, how do you communicate? Does your partner understand your signals? Would direct communication help?

questions.text: What's hardest for me to say to you?

therapeutic.rationale: What's hardest to say reveals attachment vulnerabilities. Need-saying difficulty suggests avoidant attachment; space-asking difficulty suggests anxious attachment; fear-expressing difficulty suggests catastrophizing; hurt-expressing difficulty suggests conflict avoidance. The hardest thing to say is often the most important.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different communication difficulties need different support. The partner who can't say 'I need you' needs patience; the partner who can't ask for space needs permission.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared communication difficulties may create gaps. If you both struggle to express hurt, conflicts may go unresolved.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the hardest thing for you to say to your partner? Why? What would happen if you said it?

questions.text: How do I share my emotional needs with you?
choices: I wait for you to notice and ask

therapeutic.rationale: Need-sharing style reflects attachment security. Direct-sharers have secure attachment; hint-givers test responsiveness; pushed-only sharers protect vulnerability; wait-for-noticers test attunement. Clear need-sharing dramatically improves relationship satisfaction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different need-sharing styles require adaptation. The hint-giver may feel unheard by the literal partner; the direct-sharer may overwhelm the pushed-only sharer. Learn each other's communication style.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared need-sharing makes understanding easier. Two direct-sharers will know exactly what each other needs; two hint-givers may miss each other's signals.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you share your emotional needs? Does your partner understand? Would clearer communication help your relationship?

questions.text: When I want to feel closer, I typically:
choices: Ask directly for what I need

therapeutic.rationale: Closeness-seeking styles reflect attachment and love languages. Conversation-initiators connect through words; affection-increasers connect through touch; thoughtful-doers connect through acts; direct-askers have secure communication. Understanding how your partner seeks closeness helps you recognize and respond to their bids.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different closeness-seeking may be missed. The touch-increaser's bid may not register for the conversation-seeker. Notice each other's closeness bids.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared closeness-seeking makes connection natural. You'll both reach out in ways the other recognizes and receives.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you seek closeness? Does your partner recognize your bids? How could you make your closeness-seeking clearer?

questions.text: How do I respond when you share something vulnerable?
choices: I move closer and offer comfort
I try to help solve the problem
I match with my own vulnerability

therapeutic.rationale: Vulnerability response reveals comfort with emotional closeness. Comfort-movers co-regulate well; careful-listeners provide safe space; problem-solvers may miss emotional need; matchers create mutual vulnerability. How you respond to vulnerability determines whether your partner will share again.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different vulnerability responses can disconnect. The problem-solver may frustrate the comfort-needer; the matcher may overwhelm the careful-listener. Ask: 'What would help right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vulnerability responses create predictable safety. You know how each other will respond because you'd respond the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when your partner is vulnerable? Does this help them? What would make them feel safer opening up?
